name.text: Calculating the area of a sector

questiontext.text:
Ekadeli opened a door whose width is {@r@} \(\text{m}\). The door is fixed at a point O. As the door opened, it swept the flow through an angle of {@theta_deg@}\(^\circ\). The figure below shows the part of the floor through which the door swept. Calculate the area through which the door swept. (Use \(\pi=\frac{22}{7}\))

[[jsxgraph]] var board = JXG.JSXGraph.initBoard(divid, { boundingbox: [-10, 15, 15, -10], axis: false, showCopyright: false, showNavigation: false }); // Center point O var O = board.create('point', [0, 0], { name: 'O', fixed: true, size: 0, showInfobox: false, visible: false, label: { visible: false } }); var pointO = board.create('point', [0, 0], { name: 'O', visible: false, label: { visible: true, offset: [-10, -10], fontSize: 16 } }); // Angle BOA = 60 degrees var angleDeg = {#theta_deg#}; var angleRad = angleDeg * Math.PI / 180; var radius = {#r#}; // 7 cm // Points A and B on the circle with radius 7 var A = board.create('point', [radius, -1], { name: 'A', fixed: true, size: 0, showInfobox: false, visible: false, label: { visible: false } }); var B = board.create('point', [radius * Math.cos(angleRad), radius * Math.sin(angleRad)], { name: 'B', fixed: true, size: 0, showInfobox: false, visible: false, label: { visible: false } }); // Draw the arc indicating angle BOA var angleArc = board.create('sector', [O, A, B], { radius: 1.5, fillColor: 'lightgray', strokeColor: 'blue', strokeWidth: 1, withLabel: false }); // Add angle label board.create('text', [ 1, 0.3, function() { return '{#theta_deg#}°'; } ], { fontSize: 14 }); // Add label for length AO = 7 cm board.create('text', [ function() { return (O.X() + A.X()) / 2.7; }, function() { return (O.Y() + A.Y()) / 2.7 - 1; }, '{#r#} m' ], { fontSize: 14 }); [[/jsxgraph]]

\(\text{Area through which the door swept is}\) [[input:ans1]] \(m^2\)[[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
We’re given:

  • The door acts like a radius of a circle, sweeping through an angle of {@theta_deg@}\(^\circ\)
  • \(\text{Radius r}={@r@}\, \text{m}\)
  • \(\text{Angle}\,\theta={@theta_deg@}\)
  • \(\pi={@pi_val@}\)

The area swept is a sector of a circle, and the formula for the area of a sector is:

\(\text{Area}=\frac{\theta}{360} \times {@pi_val@} r^2\)

Substitute the values:

\(\begin{align} \text{Area} &=\frac{{@theta_deg@}}{360} \times {@pi_val@} \times ({@r@})^2\\ &={@ theta_frac@} \times {@pi_val@} \times {@r_square@} \\ &= {@ theta_frac@} \times {@solution@}\\ &={@area@}\,\text{m}^2 \end{align}\)

Therefore,

Area through which the door swept is {@Area@}\(\text{m}^2\)

truefeedback.text:
It looks like you used the formula for arc length instead of the formula for the area of the sector. You may have done something like this:

\(\textbf{Arc length}=\frac{\theta}{360^\circ} \times 2 \pi r\)

This gives the distance along the curved edge of the door's swing, not the area of the floor that the door actually swept through.

\(\textbf{What You Should Do Instead:}\)

Use the area of a sector formula:

\(\text{Area}= \frac{\theta}{360^\circ} \times \pi r^2\)
